Sums

Just a written article about sums, itâ€™s outside of class material, but it caught my eye when you guys asked. Iâ€™ll just write more about sums and summing in general.

When we have a sum, itâ€™s a repeated adding of numbers, either complex, real, or any domain. The rules for adding something change, but weâ€™ll stick to regular addition with real numbers.

The most basic sum is $a + b$ where a is real and b is real. All numbers are really sums. We can add more if we want! We can have $a + b + c$ too. If we keep going we have a long series of sums: $a + b + c + \dots + f$.

When the way we are summing has a general pattern as in a functionâ€™s image like $f(x) = 3x$, we can condense what we mean over

  1. a domain
  2. the form (functionâ€™s image)

and use whatâ€™s called sigma notation to express what we mean. For example, we can have

\[\sum_{x = 1}^{7} 3x\]

to mean

\[3 + 6 + \dots + 21\]

all without having to write out the entire series above. Time saving, right?

(all an illustration).
